fail.name: fail
fail.comment: This handles failures given a textual decription

failMatch.name: failMatch
failMatch.comment: This handles failures given the actual value, the unittest/matcher.DefaultFailureHandler.failMatch.matcher the unittest/matcher.DefaultFailureHandler.failMatch.reason (argument from unittest/matcher.expect), some additonal unittest/matcher.DefaultFailureHandler.failMatch.matchState generated by the unittest/matcher.DefaultFailureHandler.failMatch.matcher, and a verbose flag which controls in some cases how much unittest/matcher.DefaultFailureHandler.failMatch.matchState information is used. It will use these to create a detailed error message (typically by calling an unittest/matcher.ErrorFormatter) and then call unittest/matcher.DefaultFailureHandler.fail with this message.

hashCode.name: hashCode
hashCode.comment:
Get a hash code for this object.

All objects have hash codes. Hash codes are guaranteed to be the same for objects that are equal when compared using the equality operator ==. Other than that there are no guarantees about the hash codes. They will not be consistent between runs and there are no distribution guarantees.

If a subclass overrides unittest/matcher.DefaultFailureHandler.hashCode it should override the equality operator as well to maintain consistency.

runtimeType.name: runtimeType
runtimeType.comment: A representation of the runtime type of the object.

==.comment:
The equality operator.

The default behavior for all dart-core.Objects is to return true if and only if this and unittest/matcher.DefaultFailureHandler.==.other are the same object.

Override this method to specify a different equality relation on a class. The overriding method must still be an equivalence relation. That is, it must be:

  • Total: It must return a boolean for all arguments. It should never throw or return null.

  • Reflexive: For all objects o, o == o must be true.

  • Symmetric: For all objects o1 and o2, o1 == o2 and o2 == o1 must either both be true, or both be false.

  • Transitive: For all objects o1, o2, and o3, if o1 == o2 and o2 == o3 are true, then o1 == o3 must be true.

The method should also be consistent over time, so equality of two objects should not change over time, or at least only change if one of the objects was modified.

If a subclass overrides the equality operator it should override the unittest/matcher.DefaultFailureHandler.hashCode method as well to maintain consistency.

fail.name: fail
fail.comment: This handles failures given a textual decription

failMatch.name: failMatch
failMatch.comment: This handles failures given the actual value, the unittest/matcher.DefaultFailureHandler.failMatch.matcher the unittest/matcher.DefaultFailureHandler.failMatch.reason (argument from unittest/matcher.expect), some additonal unittest/matcher.DefaultFailureHandler.failMatch.matchState generated by the unittest/matcher.DefaultFailureHandler.failMatch.matcher, and a verbose flag which controls in some cases how much unittest/matcher.DefaultFailureHandler.failMatch.matchState information is used. It will use these to create a detailed error message (typically by calling an unittest/matcher.ErrorFormatter) and then call unittest/matcher.DefaultFailureHandler.fail with this message.

noSuchMethod.name: noSuchMethod
noSuchMethod.comment:
unittest/matcher.DefaultFailureHandler.noSuchMethod is invoked when users invoke a non-existent method on an object. The name of the method and the arguments of the invocation are passed to unittest/matcher.DefaultFailureHandler.noSuchMethod in an dart-core.Invocation. If unittest/matcher.DefaultFailureHandler.noSuchMethod returns a value, that value becomes the result of the original invocation.

The default behavior of unittest/matcher.DefaultFailureHandler.noSuchMethod is to throw a dart-core.NoSuchMethodError.

toString.name: toString
toString.comment: Returns a string representation of this object.
